nodes.bio: Complex organisms such as plants are masters of dynamic genome regulation. In addition to mastering developmental differentiation, they also retain flexibly to respond to environmental challenges. Underpinning mechanisms include fascinating metastable epigenetic phenomena – a focus of our lab. We investigate developmental transitions as well as molecular epigenetic memory systems, e.g. of past stresses. For this, our work integrates next and third generation sequencing, modern data analyses techniques (bioinformatics), epigenomics, molecular biology and classical physiology.

Interests: Enquiry-based learning and incorporating research practices/skills into classroom experiences. Facilitating experiential learning and career path exploration by Biology undergraduates. I co-direct the Canadian Site of the Amgen Biotech Experience, which equips and trains high school teachers to run hands-on Biotech labs in their classrooms (free of charge). I supervise/co-supervise at least 4 ROPs per year, principally in over the Summer terms.
courses: BIO203H5 F: Introductory Plant Morphology and Physiology
BIO314H Laboratory in Cell and Molecular Biology

affiliation: Canada Research Chair in Molecular Genetics of Biological Clocks
nodes.bio: In the Cheng lab, we seek to understand the molecular and cellular mechanisms that govern circadian rhythms in mammals using our animal model of choice, the lab mouse. We are also interested in other aspects of cellular or brain function, including neurodevelopment, neurodegeneration, neurogenesis, mood regulation, cellular metabolism, protein trafficking, and transcriptional regulation.

I design, develop and evaluate interactive biomedical communications media created to educate medical trainees and professionals. I'm also interested in helping undergraduate science students develop practical visual literacy skills to become better scientific communicators.
courses: HSC307H Visual Presentation Design for Life Sciences

nodes.bio: We seek to understand the mechanisms that govern genome organization, epigenetic gene regulation, and genome stability in health and disease. We combine structural biology, biochemistry, and cellular model systems.
courses: BTC2110H Topics in Biotechnology: Structural Biology in Drug Development & Biotechnology
CSB1021H Structural Biology in Drug Development & Biotechnology

nodes.bio: I am broadly interested in the molecular ecology of coastal fishes and invertebrates. The central theme of my research program is understanding the patterns, causes, and consequences of dispersal and gene flow in the ocean. Current research topics in my lab include: (1) disentangling historical and contemporary factors that shape the distribution of genetic variation in natural populations; (2) understanding how (and when) kin structure emerges in marine populations; and (3) exploring the usefulness of genomic data to support sustainable fisheries and marine conservation efforts.

Research in the Dillon Lab focusses on tracking how novel infectious diseases emerge, identifying genetic loci that direct disease emergence, and characterizing the evolutionary pathways that enable opportunistic pathogens to infect new hosts. They address these problems using a variety of techniques in the fields of evolutionary genetics and microbiology, including comparative genomics, bioinformatics, and experimental evolution. </br> (Opportunities: The Dillon Lab is a growing research group with multiple fully funded MSc and PhD positions. Undergraduate positions are also available through the Research Opportunity Program (ROP) and Biology Research Course (BIO481). You can find more information about current opportunities on my lab website.)

My teaching and research are in 3D and 2D biomedical visualization and animation and its use in the creation of complex science educational media. In addition to supervising graduate students in the creation of such media, and the development and delivery of courses on related topics, I am also directly involved in the creation of visual media focused on undergraduate education in Biology. Another area practical research in which I am involved concerns 3D forensic facial approximation and the visual communication of this unique type of data to the public.
keyword: Forensic Visualization, Approximation, Reconstruction, Illustration, Education
courses: HSC404H Advanced Visual Media for Anthropological Data

nodes.bio: The importance of photosynthesis and carbon uptake by forests in defining the extent and scale of predicted future global environmental change is a major theme of my research. Our research investigates interactions of temperature, photoperiod, water availability and biotic stresses, and how metabolic imbalances caused by these stresses are used as signals for the regulation of primary carbon and isoprenoid metabolism of trees. We combine laboratory and field observations to investigate the factors impacting metabolism and photosynthesis of trees from molecular to leaf, species and ecosystem level.
keyword: Ecophysiology and Molecular Biology of Trees

nodes.bio: Our lab's goal is to understand how complex neural circuits develop from an initial population of stem cells. As a model system, we use the Drosophila optic lobe, which is the visual processing center of the fruit fly brain.

I am a science educator and a palaeontologist. My teaching approaches are designed to motivate learning and support personal and collaborative growth while helping students build observational, critical thinking, and inquiry skills in biology. I complement my teaching with pedagogical research on the role and impact of student motivation in undergraduate courses and approaches in field-based teaching and learning. I am also interested in functional morphology and locomotion in birds. Specifically, I study the evolution of skeletal features indicative of aquatic locomotion in birds.
courses: BIO208 Foundations of Human Anatomy and Physiology I
BIO209 Foundations of Human Anatomy and Physiology II

nodes.position: Professor, Director of the MSc in Biomedical Communications
affiliation: Director of the Master of Science in Biomedical Communications
nodes.bio: My research focuses on the role that visual representations play in learning. This includes investigation along various lines of inquiry including the efficacy of visual media within different learning contexts, the design of visual representations for optimal impact, and the development of standards of visual communication in the scientific visualization community. In the Biomedical Communications graduate program, I teach Research Methods for Visual Communication and Information Design and Data Visualization.

My lab's research bridges the diverse questions and techniques from community ecology, genetics and evolution. Our interests are broad, but all aspects of research in the lab seek to understand the dynamic interplay between the ecology and evolution of species interactions, particularly as it relates to plant-animal interactions. Much of our current research focuses how humans are altering the ecology and evolution of life through climate change, urbanization and other anthropogenic disturbances.

I study the ecology of biological invasions. My current research focusses on factors limiting invasions by non-native plants at high latitudes. Other recent research has centred on the question of whether escape from natural enemies (herbivores and pathogens) promotes the survival and spread of exotic plants, and whether escape from these enemies is more likely in marginal populations. I also have a longstanding interest in the effects of grazing by northern populations of geese.
keyword: Ecology of Plant Populations and Communities
courses: BIO332 Biology Field Research (Arctic Field Ecology)

nodes.bio: The goals of my research program are to study how cells, tissues and organ systems are regulated and integrated by neurons and neuroendocrine pathways that utilize a variety of neuroactive chemicals, receptors and second messengers. We determine how these systems participate in successful behaviours, using a variety of insect models. Our current research objectives involve discovery in the medically-important disease vector, Rhodnius prolixus, where we examine the integrative control of blood-gorging, homeostasis, reproduction, and the identification and molecular characterization of signaling pathways. Our scientific approach is holistic and incorporates multi-facetted aspects from gene to behaviour.

affiliation: Tier 1 Canada Research Chair in Mechanisms and Features of Social Behaviour
Senior Fellow in the CIFAR program on Child and Brain Development
nodes.bio: We study social networks and how the social environment influences individual behaviour.
We are interested in the circuit mechanisms underlying the orchestration of the ocular motor behavior and visual information processing, which is essential for proper vision.
courses: BIO408 Neural Circuit Structure and Function

nodes.bio: BMC faculty member since 1988. Academic interests listed below.
keyword: History of Medical and Scientific Illustration
courses: HSC200H Imaging Technologies for Scientific Visual Communication
HSC404H Advanced Visual Media for Anthropological Data

nodes.bio: I am a freshwater ecologist with research interests in how processes act across spatial scales to affect community structure and species distributions. At the local scale I am particularly interested in how predator-prey interactions affect community structure, while at the regional scale I have investigated the role of dispersal in shaping communities and species distributions.

We use a combination of field and lab-based experiments to study how environmental conditions affect insect evolutionary ecology.  Current and ongoing research in the lab includes (1) Ecological constraints on sexual selection; (2) Life history evolution in response to environmental change; (3) The effect of salinity pollution on freshwater populations and communities.

Our research explores how aquatic animals respond to changes in the environment (e.g. temperature) via changes in their physiology (e.g. lipid profiles) and ecology (e.g. feeding behavior). We are also interested in the ramifications of these organism-level responses for the structure and stability of food webs. We combine theory with field-based methods in Arctic seas, temperate lakes and tropical floodplains. These study systems all share drastic seasonal fluctuations in environmental characteristics.
courses: BIO313 Methods and Experimental Design in Ecology

nodes.bio: The genetic variation required for evolution by natural selection is generated by mutation, which creates new variants, and recombination, which shuffles those variants into new combinations. In my lab we combine experimental evolution, computational biology, population genetics and genomics to uncover how the generation of variation at the molecular level interacts with genetic drift and natural selection to drive patterns of biological diversity.

My research focuses on developing and evaluating novel data visualization and interaction methods and tools for knowledge discovery, interpretation, and communication in molecular biology. I teach courses on web-based health and science communication, interactive media design and development, and biomolecular visualization.

Our lab is working to understand how genetic changes lead to differences in traits and how this impacts evolution. This is important as a quarter of individuals are carriers of a gene variant that can cause disease. Despite genetic screening efforts, it is still not possible for scientists to identify which variants are pathogenic and which are benign. Our lab uses synthetic biology, robotics, and high-throughput technologies to pave the way for an atlas of disease causing mutations. We also frame these findings in an evolutionary synthesis to guide us towards acquiring an understanding of our evolutionary history.

Neuroscientist and former biotechnology analyst in investment banking.  My focus is on the the Digital Health Technology stream in the MBiotech program.  Teaching areas are medical device regulation, clinical trial design, drug development and critical thinking in data analysis.  3D printing is part of all my courses.  My research areas:  digital biomarkers, wearable technology, clinical trial failure rates and medical device regulation. Geek side: Dungeons & Dragons, World of Warcraft, 40k.

The central theme of my research program is the functioning of the nervous system, using insects as experimental models.  We are establishing the mechanisms by which the nervous system communicates information; examining hormonal, synaptic, and modulatory mechanisms, using neurophysiological, neurochemical, endocrinological, and molecular biological techniques. In particular, we are interested in the role of peptides and amines as neurohormones, released into the blood to co-ordinate activities of diverse groups of tissues, and as neuromodulators, modulating the ongoing activities of distinct pathways.

My research focuses on the regulation and control of plant terpenoid biosynthesis. We use mass spectrometry to study central terpenoid metabolism in Arabidopsis and specialized metabolism in glandular trichomes of medically important plant species.
courses: BIO368H5 Medicinal Plants and Human Health
CSB1021LEC137 Mass Spectrometry for Biological Systems

nodes.bio: My students and I study the auditory neuroethology and cognitive ecology of echolocating bats, focusing on acoustic signal production and reception for the purposes of locating prey and discriminating good food from bad. We also study the design and evolution of hearing and defensive signals in moths and other insects with bat-detecting ears.
courses: BIO405 Evolutionary Perspectives on Cognition and Behaviour

nodes.bio: My research focuses on the public understanding of science, combatting science misinformation, the science of learning, equity in STEM education, and how we learn from failure. I use the science of learning to develop evidence-informed pedagogical approaches that we can apply to higher education. Undergraduate research students are always welcome to apply for ROP positions.
keyword: Equity and Bias in STEM Education
courses: BIO152H Introduction to Evolution and Evolutionary Genetics

nodes.bio: Vertebrate Paleontology. During much of my career I have studied the evolution of terrestrial vertebrates with a focus on the origin of amniotes, their anatomy, phylogeny and ecology. Paleozoic amniotes not only record the first successful adaptation of vertebrates to a fully terrestrial mode of life, but are also at the base of subsequent adaptive radiations that eventually gave rise to modern reptiles, birds and mammals. These fossils therefore provide a unique opportunity for studies of the origin and evolutionary radiation of all amniotes. I have also studied the anatomy, embryology and growth, and evolutionary relationships of a variety of other vertebrates, including lungfish, dissorophoid amphibians, diadectomorph tetrapods, and basal dinosaurs.
courses: BIO 354H5 S Vertebrate Form and Function
BIO356G5 S Major features of Vertebrate Evolution

nodes.bio: The lab’s research is focused on understanding how neural circuits enable perception, memory, and decision-making. Using mice as a model system, Dr. Resulaj’s lab currently uses techniques and approaches such as electrophysiology, behaviour, and optogenetics to study short term memory, and its role in visual cognition.

Our research focuses on understanding the functions of regulatory elements in gene expression associated with human development and disease. We study how a unique cell type is specified and maintained by regulatory elements in the central nervous system during mammalian development. To understand these processes, we use cutting-edge molecular, cellular, and computational approaches. They include embryonic stem cell differentiation, transgenic mouse models, genomic mapping, and CRISPR-based genome editing techniques.
courses: BIO419 Molecular Aspects of Gene Regulation

nodes.bio: My biological research centres on impacts of human activities on animals in natural and urban settings. My pedagogical work investigates the effects of co-teaching and the factors influencing incidences of plagiarism.
courses: JBH471H5 Worlds Colliding: The History and Ecology of Exploration, Contact, and Exchange

nodes.bio: In the Senatore lab, we study the molecular biology, electrophysiology, protein complexing, and evolution of voltage-gated calcium channels and synaptic receptors that are activated by glutamate and glycine (i.e., ionotropic glutamate receptors) as well as protons and neuropeptides (i.e., degenerin/ENaC sodium channels). Additionally, we explore the contributions of these various channels and receptors to cellular physiology and signaling in some of the most divergent animal lineages.
keyword: Evolution of Ion Channels and Neurotransmitter Receptors

nodes.bio: My research focuses on the molecular ecology of aquatic microorganisms. As the major primary producers in freshwater and marine ecosystems, phytoplankton are key components of aquatic food webs and biogeochemical cycles. Moreover, the discovery of abundant viruses in all aquatic environments suggest that they are important agents of phytoplankton mortality. Thus, my research focuses on the role of viruses in phytoplankton population and community ecology. To better understand the complex interactions of phytoplankton and their viruses, I use quantitative molecular techniques to examine their community composition and dynamics in natural environments and laboratory cultures.

My research employs molecular and traditional tools addressing plant systematics questions at both higher and lower taxonomic level as well as molecular mechanisms underlying organellar genome evolution in plants.

Our research studies development and physiology of nerve and muscle. We use a variety of genetic, molecular, biochemical, imaging and electrophysiological techniques to describe and understand the cellular and molecular mechanisms that contribute to the proper growth and function of these tissues, in health and disease.

Spatial Ecology: Assess spatial patterns within populations and communities to infer underlying processes and assembly rules. Metacommunity dynamics: Relate scale-dependent components of species diversity within and among community to landscape structure and landscape change. Landscape Genetics: Provide a mechanistic link by testing landscape effects on gene flow.

My research interests include graphic medicine, patient education, the visual construction of gender in medical discourse, the history of medical and bioscientific illustration, and the socio-cultural dimensions of medical visualization. I teach courses in bioscientific, pathological, and neuroanatomical illustration, and in graphic medicine. As Illustrator-in-Residence in the Temerty Faculty of Medicine, I conduct elective workshops in the visual medical humanities and the use of comics to build empathy and reflective capacity in the training of healthcare professionals.
keyword: Visual Representations of Sex and Gender

nodes.bio: My research focuses on how memory is encoded in rodents at the molecular level, and how these molecular changes support the establishment and persistence of a memory. Even though we have known of the molecular basis of memory for over a decade, how the molecular events sum together to give rise to memory is still not understood. Currently I am focused on “transient” players in memory formation, focusing on mRNA modifications, specifically methylation and how RNA methylation is used during memory formation.
courses: BIO483 Molecular Mechanisms of Memory Formation

nodes.bio: I conduct research in risk visualization, cell and molecular modelling, and mobile applications in health. I co-authored with Michael J. Wiley Anatomy 300/303 Interactive Lab Companion, and co-authored with Jason Sharpe and Charles Lumsden In Silico: 3D Animation and Simulation of Cell Biology with Maya and MEL, a book on 3D graphics programming in biological visualization. From 2008-2019 I was the Director of the Master of Science in Biomedical Communications program. In the Masters program, I teach the first half of MSC2003Y (Biomedical Communications technology), which focuses on introductory organic modelling, and MSC2015H (Interpretive Visualization: Cinematic Design and Preproduction), in which students develop scripts storyboards and animatics, in order to design cinematic stories.
